title: To Kill a Mockingbird
description: A classic novel about racial injustice in the American South. Set in the 1930s, it follows young Scout Finch as she observes her father, lawyer Atticus Finch, defend a black man falsely accused of a crime. The story explores themes of prejudice, compassion, and the loss of innocence through the eyes of its child narrator.

A dystopian novel set in a totalitarian society where the government exercises complete control over every aspect of people's lives. The story follows Winston Smith, a low-ranking party member who begins to question the oppressive regime. As Winston rebels against the system, readers are confronted with themes of surveillance, manipulation of truth, and the power of language.

title: Pride and Prejudice
description: A romantic novel of manners set in Georgian England, focusing on the Bennet family and their five daughters. The story primarily follows the intelligent and spirited Elizabeth Bennet as she navigates societal expectations, misconceptions, and her complicated relationship with the proud Mr. Darcy. Through witty dialogue and keen social observations, Austen critiques the marriage customs and class divisions of her time.

title: The Great Gatsby
description: A novel depicting the excesses of the Jazz Age in America, told through the eyes of narrator Nick Carraway. It centers on the mysterious millionaire Jay Gatsby and his obsession with the beautiful Daisy Buchanan. The story explores themes of decadence, idealism, social upheaval, and the American Dream, set against the backdrop of the Roaring Twenties.

title: One Hundred Years of Solitude
description: A landmark of magical realism exploring generations of the Buendía family in the fictional town of Macondo. The novel weaves together the extraordinary and the mundane, blending historical events with fantastical elements. Through the family's saga, Márquez explores themes of solitude, fate, and the cyclical nature of time and history.

title: The Catcher in the Rye
description: A coming-of-age story focused on teenage angst and alienation, narrated by the cynical Holden Caulfield. The novel follows Holden's experiences in New York City after being expelled from his prep school. Through his encounters and reflections, the book explores themes of innocence, identity, and the challenges of transitioning from adolescence to adulthood.

title: The Lord of the Rings
description: An epic high-fantasy trilogy set in the fictional world of Middle-earth, following the hobbit Frodo Baggins on his quest to destroy the One Ring. The story encompasses a vast array of characters, races, and landscapes as Frodo and his companions battle against the dark lord Sauron. Tolkien's work explores themes of power, corruption, friendship, and the triumph of good over evil.

title: The Hobbit
description: A children's fantasy novel that serves as a prequel to The Lord of the Rings, following the adventures of Bilbo Baggins. The story recounts Bilbo's unexpected journey with a group of dwarves to reclaim their homeland from the dragon Smaug. Along the way, Bilbo encounters various creatures and finds the mysterious ring that will play a crucial role in the later trilogy.

title: Brave New World
description: A dystopian novel exploring a genetically modified future society where stability is prioritized over individuality and emotion. The story follows Bernard Marx, an outsider in this seemingly perfect world, as he grapples with the limitations of his society. Huxley's work raises questions about the cost of happiness, the role of technology, and the nature of freedom.

title: The Chronicles of Narnia
description: A series of fantasy novels set in the magical world of Narnia, blending elements of myth, fairy tale, and Christian allegory. The books follow various children from our world as they are transported to Narnia and become involved in its history and conflicts. Throughout the series, Lewis explores themes of good versus evil, faith, and personal growth.

title: The Hunger Games
description: A dystopian novel where youths compete in a televised battle to the death as a form of government control and entertainment. The story follows Katniss Everdeen as she volunteers to take her sister's place in the deadly games. As Katniss fights for survival, she becomes a symbol of rebellion against the oppressive Capitol.

title: The Da Vinci Code
description: A thriller involving a conspiracy within the Catholic Church, following symbologist Robert Langdon as he unravels a complex mystery. The novel combines elements of art history, cryptography, and religious symbolism in a fast-paced adventure. Brown's work sparked controversy and debate about the historical accuracy of its claims regarding Jesus Christ and Mary Magdalene.

title: Moby-Dick
description: An epic tale of obsession and adventure on the high seas, following Captain Ahab's relentless pursuit of the white whale, Moby Dick. The novel is narrated by Ishmael, a sailor aboard the whaling ship Pequod. Melville's work explores themes of good and evil, the nature of obsession, and humanity's relationship with the natural world.

title: Jane Eyre
description: A Gothic romance following the life of its eponymous heroine, from her troubled childhood to her role as a governess at Thornfield Hall. The novel chronicles Jane's moral and spiritual development, as well as her complex relationship with the enigmatic Mr. Rochester. Brontë's work addresses issues of class, sexuality, religion, and feminism in Victorian society.

title: The Odyssey
description: An ancient Greek epic poem detailing Odysseus' journey home after the Trojan War, facing numerous challenges and mythical creatures. The story also follows the struggles of Odysseus' wife Penelope and son Telemachus as they deal with suitors vying for Penelope's hand. Homer's epic explores themes of heroism, loyalty, and the nature of home.

title: Crime and Punishment
description: A psychological thriller exploring guilt, morality, and redemption, centered on the impoverished student Raskolnikov. The novel follows Raskolnikov's mental anguish after he murders a pawnbroker, believing himself to be above moral law. Dostoevsky's work delves deep into the psychology of crime and the nature of justice.

title: Wuthering Heights
description: A passionate and dark tale of love and revenge set on the Yorkshire moors, focusing on the relationship between Catherine Earnshaw and Heathcliff. The novel spans two generations, exploring the destructive effects of jealousy and vengeance. Brontë's work challenges Victorian ideals and explores the nature of love, social class, and the supernatural.

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray
description: A philosophical novel about the pursuit of pleasure and the nature of beauty, following the story of Dorian Gray, who sells his soul to maintain his youth and beauty. As Dorian indulges in a hedonistic lifestyle, his portrait ages and reflects the corruption of his soul. Wilde's novel explores themes of aestheticism, morality, and the dangers of vanity.

title: The Grapes of Wrath
description: A powerful novel depicting the struggles of migrant workers during the Great Depression, following the Joad family as they leave Oklahoma for California. The story alternates between the Joads' journey and broader commentaries on the social and economic conditions of the time. Steinbeck's work addresses themes of man's inhumanity to man, the strength of family, and the dignity of the human spirit.

title: Frankenstein
description: A Gothic horror novel exploring the dangers of unchecked scientific ambition, telling the story of Victor Frankenstein and his creation. The novel follows the creature's experiences and eventual turn to violence as he is rejected by society. Shelley's work raises questions about the nature of humanity, the responsibilities of creators, and the consequences of playing God.

title: Don Quixote
description: A Spanish novel following the adventures of a man who loses his sanity reading chivalric romances and decides to become a knight-errant. Accompanied by his faithful squire Sancho Panza, Don Quixote embarks on a series of comical and poignant misadventures. Cervantes' work satirizes the chivalric romances of his time while exploring themes of idealism, reality, and the power of imagination.

title: The Count of Monte Cristo
description: An adventure novel of betrayal, imprisonment, escape, and elaborate revenge, following Edmond Dantès as he transforms himself into the mysterious Count of Monte Cristo. The story spans many years as Dantès meticulously plans and executes his vengeance against those who wronged him. Dumas' work explores themes of justice, vengeance, mercy, and the consequences of obsession.
